Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: My phone buzzes just as I’m about to dive back into the code review. It’s Sam, my oldest friend, and his voice is frantic—he’s halfway to the airport and thinks he left his passport at home. “Can you check? And if it’s here, can you bring it? My flight’s in two hours.” I promise to look, but as I hang up, my eyes flicker back to my screen. The new feature I’ve been building for weeks is almost done, but the code review is full of red flags about performance. My team expects me to fix these issues before the end of the day; the release is tomorrow, and everyone’s counting on me to deliver clean, efficient code. I feel the pressure mounting—Sam needs me now, but so does my team. My mind races, torn between the urgency of a friend in crisis and the professional responsibility I can’t ignore. My hands hover over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I try to figure out what to do next.
